title: We've begun 24/7 moderation. Hooray!
body:
Hey all!

Just wanted to pop in to let you know that we have begun ramping up moderation of the beta boards as part of preparation for the next stage of development. We're actively working to make our universal guidelines much clearer, but as we do so, we'd love to hear any feedback, ideas, or whatever you feel compelled to share with us, specifically pertaining to moderation. 

Over the next couple of weeks, we'll be working with you inside the initial sub-communities to figure out how we want each of them to operate. In the meantime, please post any thoughts or moderation feedback you have in this thread.

K BYE!

replies.body: Can you make it to where a person would see a detailed reason why they were banned/their thread was closed?
Yes! That will be a mandatory thing that we have to do whenever we delete a post, or ban someone. The reason we take action will be SUPER clear. :)
This is where I'm sad I'm limited to one upvote. =)
Is this only applied to the community beta or the league forums as well?
Are we going to have ghost mods like on the regular forums? Because if we are, I am not coming back. They are terrible.

If you're asking if they'll be actively posting then the answer is no. They'll have a light footprint, but that could always change in the future. 

Frankly, moderation isn't very exciting. It's a necessary evil, but when it's working properly, you shouldn't even notice that it's happening. That is, unless you've done something that required moderation. I want the moderation process, and all activity surrounding that process to be invisible to the average user. Does that make sense?
I don't agree or disagree with you right now. I am curious, though, why you want mods to be invisible to the average user?
For the same reason I personally don't feel comfortable hanging around a police officer. Even if I haven't done anything wrong, it makes me feel threatened and uncomfortable.

I don't really like this analogy. I don't view mod posts as being akin to having a cop driving behind you the whole way home. I view them like seeing a cop that has pulled someone over on the highway for speeding. As a driver that doesn't make me think 'Oh no I'm next!' it makes me think 'Good, people be driving crazy out here' And then next time I get cut off, I think 'don't worry, he'll get pulled over eventually'. Currently every time I get cut off (see obvious rule breaking posts/threads) I think 'Boy I wish we had a police force'. 

Which I guess is maybe somewhat testable. You could do a survey and ask forum users how often you think the forums are moderated. Because the two comments I always see, are "The forums aren't moderated" or "The mods ban you for literally nothing". The later being people very likely got banned for obvious rule violations, obviously. But I feel like the majority of posters who haven't had mod action taken on their posts, think the forums are a lawless wasteland with no moderators.

tl;dr Constant cops trailing you = scary. Visibility that cops protect you = reassuring. Strike a balance please.

edit; Maybe if posts about mod action weren't highlighted  by the 'riot post in this thread' button. So if you were in the thread you'd know, but on the front page it would be invisible? That way you can notice it in passing, but it doesn't demand attention.

While we're back on this topic, can I suggest that whenever mod actions are taken, the reason behind their action is visible to the general public, as well as to the offender? This...

1. prevents false accusations by the offender, or others.
2. helped the community know what kinds of posts are acceptable - ex: when I see that a post has been deleted for racism, now I know that racism isn't acceptable on these forums.
3. is a reassurance that mods aren't being inactive
4. is a reassurance that my threads won't get deleted (because I see the types of things that *do* get deleted, and know that my threads aren't that).

I think this can be flipped to better state what I'm seeing a lot of other people say. Mods shouldn't be "that police officer in the corner" but that sheriff in a close knit town. You know their name, they help the community where they can and try to be a good role model. Oh, and they also carry a gun. 

The fact is, mods (and even cops as well for that matter) shouldn't be known as "the guys that can ban (arrest) you". They should be helpful, well-known members of the community that can be trusted for their representation as a person and not their role. All pleasant ideals sure, but I digress.

The current system leads to a lot of confusion about the level of moderation and who is doing the moderating. I've seen people who think there are no moderators, or only spotty moderation.

That the moderation staff is hidden has led to people assuming that a non-moderator Red who was currently active on the forum had closed a thread. Compounding the confusion is the ability for the community to close a thread with downvotes, which has resulted in people not knowing whether a thread was closed by Riot or the players.

You guys can do better. Moderation shouldn't be obtrusive, but at the same time there should be information available to those who care to know.


I must also say, I find the police analogy kind of disturbing. Invisible moderation sounds more like a police state where the police are discreetly watching on you, and if you screw up they quietly haul you away.

Some of the best moderated boards I've seen have mods as active participants and posters. The community is comfortable with them because they know they're also just regular people who enjoy the same stuff they do, but also know that there is somebody ready to defend the boards against undesirable posting.

Tamat, I'm really upset. A thread I really liked got moved. And I would really like to know the reason. It's very unsettling that we can't see these mods at all or interact with them. The analogy just doesn't stand.

No, I did not make the thread, but I supported it. We need to know WHY something was moved etc. Communication. We need it. Please don't avoid it. Communicate
That's what we're moving towards, but it won't be instantaneous. Can you give me more information about the thread that was moved?

I can see why you think this, but I actually think the ability for the average user to see negative actions and their repercussions as a benefit. People on forums come from an incredibly large amount of different backgrounds, societies and age groups with their own conversational lines. i.e. a stereotypical teenager starting high school will think shouting profanities and possibly the occasional racist comment is funny and not malicious, but naturally this won't be a good thing to have. While I'm not one for  making an example out of someone wouldn't it make sense to give the average user the option of seeing what *actions* cause what response?

Where I'm going with this is, yes, I don't think moderation should be **actively advertised** or we would develop a police state mentality and stifle open voice, as you said. But I do think if someone chooses to look for either malicious content or specifically moderation activity (maybe a separate tracker? Just an idea) then they won't develop a "they're after me" way of thinking. Names and other undesirable pictures/videos can be blacked out in this hypothetical "Mod Tracker" post as well, as long as the bannable actions are shown.

To use your example of a police officer, it would be like going and watching an episode of Cops, not only would it show that mods are out there doing they're job, it would also reinforce the actions that were taken down as something that shouldn't be done. Yes, downvoting in the CB's current iteration does this to a point, but I think we can all agree there are some posts, comments and other actions that shouldn't be allowed time or even a place at the bottom and moderator action should be taken.

Of course there are cons to this idea as there is for any system, like increased scrutiny/pressure to mod actions and possible specific mod heckling, which could negatively affect Mod-user relationships if not handled correctly among other possible issues, but I think they're workable.
---

Tl;dr (imho) moderator action should be **available** to be publicly seen but not **advertised**.

> Tl;dr (imho) moderator action should be **available** to be publicly seen but not **advertised**.

I have a hard time understanding the value that something like this would bring the average user. Why would we make all mod actions available to everyone, when instead we can just make the rational available to the user that had content moderated? What you are proposing seems like a lot of work, for not a lot of value; but maybe I'm just not understanding the why yet?

I tend to tangent off to an idea like that when discussing topics sorry. Don't get too hung up on my specific idea of a tracker and such, that's just me brainstorming out loud without much consideration.

What it really boils down to, I'd rather have mods I know and trust and *see* than invisible mods who's actions I may only see once in a blue moon. The results can be exactly the same in both approaches, but the former will let me rest at ease more because I know "Rioter X will come to take this down" in a thread that deserves intervention instead of thinking "it will hopefully disappear soon". 

Trust is established off of previous actions I've seen (public disclosure of thread closures and other mod actions). If I see a Rioter's name behind an action I can put a name behind my expectations of a mod and start building a trust in that person and other mods to repeat that same action.

Invisible mods.... even if they're just as effective, I can't trust them. Was the invisible action taken by a Mod or did OP just delete it? Was this the same Mod who closed 'Y' thread last week or was it someone else? Was 'Y' thread deleted for the racism or for the naming and shaming? or both? Behind the awful tone and words choice OP made a good point, was it deleted because it portrayed Riot in a bad light? Invisible actions leave too many questions for anyone outside the offender<-->Mod relationship. And that doubt, however slight, impedes the ability to trust 'the people behind the curtain'.

tl;dr I'd rather **trust an individual** than **have blind faith in a group**.

P.S. In the end, my ideal moderator is an active member of the community who is confident enough in their actions to announce what they did and why they did it. I'm not saying you guys aren't, just that that's what I look for in a great moderator.

Sir ArmaMalum, Rauron, BrightNooblar and everyone else who has posted such thoughtful comments on this subject: Thank you!

I will take everything you've said and try to figure out a way to address your concerns and desires in a way that is realistic, and effective. This has been an extremely helpful thread, and is one that I've required all of the moderators to read carefully.
This was the most perfect reply you could have given, and not just for the personal warm fuzzies.

Thank you for reading, keeping an open mind, and (at least for my replies, I know I was very confusing at times) being patient.

We're all hoping to improve the CB, the community and League as a whole little by little, and I wish you the best of luck in that endeavor. =)
I agree wholeheartedly with this post.

My view on it is that League spans multiple cultures. That on top of differing age groups inside of those cultures will lead to different perspectives on what violates the rules. Some cultures are more accepting of profanity while others are more strict. By having examples available you provide the opportunity to not just act on the rules that are broken, but hopefully add an extra layer of prevention. It's always better to educate the community in order to avoid infractions as opposed to say "They'll figure it out and interpret it or they'll end up banned and figure it out from there". That's my take on what he's trying to say here. No guarantee I'm anywhere close.

Pretty much this. Where I'm coming from is taking very basic child psychology into this area, because as a group (not individually) I see any large Internet community as a group of children vying for attention and praise. In a very basic, broad sense.

Showing specific examples of "this is bad" and "this is good" via the voting system is good. But when mod intervention needs to happen on posts with, say, porn and racism or any non-negotiable behavior examples being made of these actions (as Mackle said elsewhere, names do not have to be shown, just the actions themselves) can show exactly what "not to do". 

And I want to say again, I'm against advertising this feature, putting it in the public's face. But anyone who visited a horrible thread and supported it will usually come back to it eventually, and a small notice is stamped on the OP saying "this thread was deleted for x reasons" then these supporters, along with anyone just as much against the thread, will see mod action was taken and may have second thoughts on repeating the behavior. This is a 'nuke' grade reaction though and ideally should not be used often, for most situations I would think the voting system (an active way of showing peer responses) would suffice.
It would be better to just read an FAQ section of rules for each section and in general that showed examples of what isn't ok, rather than using others to be made example of due to past action.

You aren't "using others" if the name of the post and the person who posted it are redacted from the example. I'm not suggesting naming and shaming, but simply having a few Riot made examples in a FAQ or guide area isn't going to do the job, because most people who are going to break these rules, aren't going to go look at the FAQ.

An FAQ cannot contain all of the details and subtleties that come up when actual people have actual interactions. Riot has often dealt with this issue by using language which is less specific, and I think that is a good approach. What it means, though, is that there isn't (for instance) a comprehensive list of banned words. There's some controversy surrounding the use of the word "rape", especially in competitive gaming communities, and some people take issue with words like "gypped" or "fag" or "gimp". Listing every problematic word and the ways in which it can or can't be used would be neither easy to do nor especially effective. Sometimes saying "get dunked, scrub" is okay in a game (when clearly joking), and sometimes it isn't. Examples help a lot more than blanket rules, and this would provide examples.

Because you're not dealing with a community of fully rational people, who see a list of rules, and assume those rules are enforced as outlined. You're dealing with a community of real people, who will doubt if things are actually done the way they have been told if they never see them being done that way. Again, going back to the cop analogy, I don't need to know every last verdict and how every case turns out. I just want to pass some guy that got pulled over now and then, so I know that the person that cut me off and ran a red light I was going to stop at, isn't just the way things are around here.

Bringing that back to forum moderation, I don't need (or really have any strong desire) to know what action the mod took against the specific user. I just want the mod to post "alright guys, this thread has turned into person attack and isn't discussing balance anymore, I'm closing it". That way I know the mods care about thread quality, and I know that everyone else knows that personal attacks get threads closed.

In a perfect world simply having a clear list of rules would work, but the world isn't perfect, and the internet is less perfect than that. And in fact, even now people post and do things that are CLEARLY against the rules (porn, racism, etc) and other people don't even blink, because they think that is just how it is here. Visibility is about assuring Joe Q Forumgoer that those things really are against the rules, and the rules really are enforced.

Edit; Again, just to be clear. I don't think people want a compendium of moderator actions they can thumb through. I think they just want a quick explanation of what rule was broken (even if it was obvious) in the thread in question. To me that doesn't sound like a lot of extra work, but maybe I've got a bad frame of reference, since I clearly make long winded posts and I've got no idea how involved the back end of forum moderation is. As for the return on the time/effort investment, its an intangible. It comes back in the forum of generic board health/mentality. Ideally public action lets disgruntled posters angry about trolls come back from the brink and make good content, rather than pull an 'If you can't beat them, join them' response and start junk posting themselves.

If nothing else, think of this in terms of consistency. The more areas in which Riot clearly displays a commitment to honesty and accountability, the more trust Riot creates in its community. By making moderation visible and clear, the community is able to see that Riot is not hiding the reasons for which that moderation happens.

Look at other issues that have come up in the past. IP gains? Very little communication, lots of distrust. Stealth rework? Long periods of silence, highly upset community. Magma Chamber? Delayed announcements and dialogue, still a sore spot for many. Most of the instances in which Riot chooses *not* to be transparent or communicative have weakened and stressed the relationship between the company and the players, which is particularly distressing when so much of the company is made up *of* players.

You do have a point that we, as posters and players, won't actually get a ton of direct value from seeing why xXJoeXJaneXx had a post deleted. In the long run, though, the fact that those reasons are available *at all* will be impactful in itself, to significant benefit.

my league got to -14:-8 in the patch i dont know where to say this but i wanted to know if anyone knew what was wrong and what i could do to patch league i exited the patcher and now when i come back it gets to 33% and stops and says send logs or continue

This is an example of a post that might be deleted because it's in the wrong area. There's a whole section for [Help & Support](http://community.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/f/osqw6G4M) that you can post these kinds of things in.

Actually, funnily enough your comment brings up a small point that has always confused me. Whenever I reply to an off-topic or hateful comment along the same lines you have (explaining why it's not good, where it should go instead, etc.) I tend to get upvoted on that reply, which in turn brings the bad comment we wanted to bury farther up in the order. It's gotten to the point occasionally where I've had to downvote my own comments to keep them from getting too high.

Again, not a big deal as I know that's how the system is intended to work, but an interesting small problem I've run into before.

Edit: Prime example being exactly what is currently happening, lol

Sir ArmaMalum is the ultimate forum good guy. The "good lawyer" from Arrested Development comes to mind.

"I shall crouch behind that garbage cart."

"I shall counter this hateful remark with sound reasoning and a heartfelt appeal to human decency, then downvote my own comment to avoid giving it additional visibility."
There are some fine tunings in the sorting strategies that we can take to address this.
So does this mean 24/7 moderations on all the forums, or just this community forum?
There's always been 24/7 moderation in the old forums, but we're ramping up to that point in these as well.

No offense meant but I know a few people who would disagree with that. One of the issues many people had with moderation on the forum had an odd rotation between "Not there at all" and "Hand of God righteous fury from above".

I think part of that has to deal with the issue of having so many subforums to moderate and such a massive influx of users making moderation spread thin but it's definitely one of the main issues many people had with the forums.

*(Again, no disrespect meant. I'm just sharing what many people thought. For what it's worth I have high hopes for what you guys are doing here!)*

I would agree with that assessment as well, but regardless of effectiveness, there's always been 24/7 moderation. That problem comes from two things:

* Lack of tools and the time required to develop new tools
* Amount of posting traffic in areas like General Discussion

We've built the new boards from the ground up, and we're spending a lot of time to develop an amazing suite of tools that will make moderation a lot easier. The biggest challenge we'll have to avoid the "God righteous fury from above" feel is creating good rules that are super clear, and that aren't prohibitive to the kind of culture we want. When we've finished those, we'll share with you to get your feedback.
Out of curiosity, are there any plans/ideas on where these rules will be physically shown on-site?
Yes, but nothing decided yet. Rules are worthless if they aren't visible and easy to find. We're thinking through that user experience flow now.

Hey Octavia. That's some pretty strong feedback. It would take a lot to make me want to quit League, so I have to assume this is a HUGE deal for you. Can you help me understand why you feel so strongly about having a GD? Seems to me that having an unorganized area of the forum just breeds a lot of craziness, and makes it extremely hard to curate awesome content. 

Help us understand why you (and anyone else who shares these views) feel so strongly about this.

It's pretty much the forum format is much more convenient compared to CB. In my opinion anyway. CB feels so...restricted.

I don't know how story threads would be possible with CB. Because it's one large post and then just a bunch of small replies. You can't really discuss things like you can on GD. 

Or that's how I feel, after using Reddit for awhile. General Discussion is only bad because it's the main forums of League of Legends, which in itself has a bad community. Discussion I feel does and can take place on GD.


By all means, I could care less if community beta gets created. Just don't delete GD for it.

Feel free to disagree with me, but that's how I feel. I have the same feelings as Octavia.

> I don't know how story threads would be possible with CB. Because it's one large post and then just a bunch of small replies. You can't really discuss things like you can on GD. 
> 

I feel like we've expressed interest in addressing this point of feedback with the "Show as Flat" option. What else could we do to support this?

I've said this before, but I'll keep saying it: my main concern is that Reddit is a news site, and this is supposed to be a discussion forum. If you copy and paste Reddit's karma rules, including karma decay, you will just have a second news site. The most salient features of Reddit's visibility system are:

1. No post, however popular, will be visible after a few days. That's plenty of time to circulate a breaking news article or an interesting link, but not enough time for a meaningful discussion.

2. Reddit only considers upvotes/downvotes, not posts, when determining visibility. I think threads with active discussion should be more visible. "Bumps" can be regulated by, e.g., only providing a visibility boost once per user per day.

I feel leddit is a move to help reds connect with players. however that's not always what we want.

sure you are a bunch of funny nice people, but we also want to make friends with other regular players like ourselves.

GD lets us recognize each other, with an avatar [from FEK] and image tools [some from fek] to joke around with each other.

sure your content might be great, but if we don't get to create some for each other with the tools introduced you are going to see your community you are trying to reach leave

as for craziness, that's elf explanatory. I wouldn't waste my time on Gd if it wasn't crazy

It's just a really cool place to hang out. I know a lot of the people there, feels like a real community. The craziness is what makes GD a unique place. Why should content be of high quality? Sometimes I just want random off-topic shitposting. I'm not very good at offering insight I guess, but when everything is so cleanly divided like with this format I feel like part of the interaction is lost. Flat view at the same time makes keeping track of conversations annoying, since people will refer to a post but you can't see the exact thing they're referring to without clicking, which I suppose defeats the purpose, but it just looks like a mess of random posts. That's the best way I can put it, maybe I'm being an idiot, but those are my feelings...also the whole custom fek avatars (which I set to the largest size setting) is nice, but that's more a bonus than anything...
Btw here's a whole thread on the subject: http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=4535826

It's a fun, chaotic place to have discussions and make friends with like-minded players. Having a dedicated "le maymays and le games xD" section doesn't work as well because half the fun is the spontaneity in the middle of serious League discussion. Say what you will about it not producing "awesome content" (whatever the hell that means, since you guys never read the player concepts and stuff on their forums), but it breeds a fun, albeit somewhat trolly and toxic, community. Have you seen how active the GD chatroom and customs are? And it's really not even confined to those, there are plenty of other subgroups in and out of game that formed due to GD's chaos.


It's a bit lame to say, but it really has developed its own culture too. As much as you guys hate that, we love it so of course we feel strongly about it. There are a bunch of other games that have an active forum community like GD, where, like GD, lots of people have as much fun posting there as they do playing the game itself. Forums are endgame. It's just that GD ended up with a scope as large as Misc., /b/, old WoW GD etc. and then developed its own character from there.

{{champion:6}} to be kidding me.

GD has spoken out about the reasons they like GD, and the reasons they hate the CB. In the thread that you popped into(which is now a week old..) you started discussing stuff with us on GD for once, which was great, but sadly you, once again, left in favor of having the discussion(which, BTW, is *about* GD) on CB. We've told you time and time again, but honestly Tamat, you just act like you're not even reading anything we say. In said thread I left a very lengthy response for you, in hopes that you would listen, but you didn't and left the thread because you are seemingly obsessed with CB. Any time we do get a response from Riot about GD, they're always shoving CB in our faces like a channel with only infomercials.

"Can you help me understand why you feel so strongly about having a GD?"

Can you help me understand why you feel so strongly about flat-out ignoring us?
